critique: This executive order, issued during World War II, establishes the Solid Fuels Administration for War within the Department of the Interior. Its primary purpose is to ensure the effective development, utilization, and distribution of solid fuels (coal) to support the war effort. The order outlines the Administrator's responsibilities, including policy formulation, coordination with other government agencies, and recommendations regarding fuel distribution, pricing, and transportation. It also addresses manpower issues and foreign solid fuels activities. The order emphasizes collaboration with existing agencies and aims to avoid conflicts with other wartime directives. Given the context of wartime mobilization, the order reflects a strong emphasis on central planning and government intervention in the economy to achieve national security objectives. There is no mention of immigration or social issues. The order does expand executive power to address the war effort. It also centralizes power at the federal level. It prioritizes national security. It also involves heavy government intervention in the economy. Finally, it is neutral on social inclusion.
